items.title: Millions of accounts culled days after social media ban started, data shows
items.description: More than 4.7 million Australian social media accounts have been deactivated since laws banning children aged under 16 took effect in December, according to data released by the government.

items.title: Study finds ocean damage nearly doubles climate cost estimates

featured_image.name: Study Finds Ocean Impacts Nearly Double Economic Cost of ...

items.description:
The economic toll of climate change on the world's oceans has been vastly underestimated, according to new research that for the first time puts a price tag on marine ecosystem degradation—findings that emerge alongside a separate study warning that proposed climate engineering solutions carry their own risks to ocean life.

Research published Wednesday in the journal Nature Climate Change by scientists at Scripps Institution of Oceanography at UC San Diego found that factoring ocean damage into climate calculations nearly doubles the global cost of carbon dioxide emissions. The study introduces what researchers call the "blue" social cost of carbon, adding $46.2 per ton of CO2 to existing estimates, bringing the total to $97.2 per ton—a 91% increase.[1][2]

items.title: Denmark says White House talks failed to shift Trump's Greenland stance

featured_image.name: Can the US put a price tag on Greenland?

items.description:
Despite President Donald Trump's intensifying push to gain control of Greenland, experts warn that the Arctic territory's severe climate, remote geography, and absent infrastructure pose obstacles that no change in sovereignty could overcome. The island's vast mineral wealth remains locked beneath ice and rock that have defied extraction efforts for decades.

"If you're going to go to Greenland for its minerals, you're talking billions upon billions upon billions of dollars and extremely long time before anything ever comes of it," mineral industry analyst Louis Marchese told Fortune, offering a sobering assessment of the mining reality.[1]

items.title: Amazon opens sovereign cloud in Germany to ease EU data fears

featured_image.name: AWS seeks to allay security fears with new European ...

items.description:
Amazon on Thursday launched its AWS European Sovereign Cloud, a new independent cloud infrastructure designed specifically for Europe that is physically and legally separate from the company's other data centers worldwide. The move addresses growing European concerns about data sovereignty and the dominance of U.S. technology companies in the region's cloud computing market.

The first AWS Region of the sovereign cloud opened in the German state of Brandenburg, which surrounds Berlin. Amazon plans to invest more than €7.8 billion in the AWS European Sovereign Cloud in Germany through 2040, according to the company, with the investment expected to support an average of 2,800 full-time equivalent jobs annually and add approximately €17.2 billion to Germany's GDP.[1][2][3]

items.title: Astronauts return to Earth in NASA’s first medical evacuation
items.description: A capsule carrying four International Space Station crew members has splashed down in the Pacific, bringing their mission to an end more than a month early.

items.title: Premier announces review into Victoria's disastrous bushfires
items.description: Jacinta Allan vows to request a formal review of the state's disastrous bushfire season, following days of questions over issues like Country Fire Authority resourcing and the state's disaster preparedness.

items.title: 'Died in the hands of her father': Negin is one of thousands of Iranians killed
items.description: Like so many Iranian Australians, Morteza Khandani has been desperate for any news of his family in Iran. Two days ago, he was able to confirm the worst. His niece, Negin Ghadimi, had been killed in anti-government protests.

items.title: Second fatal crane collapse tied to same Thai firm, minister says
items.description: A second fatal crane collapse in two days has been linked to the same construction company, a Thai minister says.

items.title: Climate report warns warming may hit catastrophic levels by 2050

featured_image.name: World warming faster than forecast as pollution cuts remove hidden ...

items.description:
Governments and financial institutions have underestimated climate change risks that could undermine the global economy, according to a new report warning that temperatures are rising faster than predicted and could hit catastrophic levels by 2050.

The Parasol Lost report, jointly produced by the Institute and Faculty of Actuaries (IFoA) and the University of Exeter, was released on Tuesday as new data from the European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service confirmed 2025 was the third-warmest year on record. For the first time, the three-year average from 2023 to 2025 has exceeded 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels — the threshold nations pledged not to breach under the 2015 Paris Agreement.[1][2]

items.title: China calls Carney visit a 'turning point' in relations

featured_image.name: China's 2025 Canadian import slump to remind visiting Carney of economic stakes

items.description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney arrived in Beijing on Wednesday for a four-day state visit, marking the first trip by a Canadian leader to China since 2017 and signaling both nations' desire to repair ties strained by years of diplomatic tensions.

items.title: Oil prices fall as Trump signals pause on Iran military action

featured_image.name: Oil prices sink more than 2% as Trump remarks calm concern about ...

items.description:
Oil prices fell for the first time in six trading sessions on Thursday after President Donald Trump indicated the United States would hold off on military action against Iran, easing fears of supply disruptions in the Middle East.

Brent crude slid more than 3% to around $64 per barrel, while West Texas Intermediate dropped to approximately $60, erasing much of the 11% gain the benchmarks had accumulated over the previous week.[1][2][3]

The retreat came after Trump said Wednesday that he had received assurances Iran would cease killing anti-government protesters. "The killing has stopped. The executions have stopped," Trump said from the Oval Office, without identifying the source of his information.[4][5]

items.title: Deadly poison may have sparked life's building blocks, study finds

featured_image.name: Once upon a time when life appeared: chemistry in the ...

items.description:
A substance deadly to humans may have been instrumental in creating the very first ingredients for life on Earth. New computer simulations reveal that frozen hydrogen cyanide crystals possess highly reactive surface facets capable of triggering chemical reactions at extremely low temperatures, according to research published this week in ACS Central Science.[1][2][3]

The findings could reshape scientific understanding of how life's essential building blocks, including amino acids and components of DNA, might have formed in the frigid environments of early Earth or on distant icy worlds like Saturn's moon Titan.

items.title: Workers lose pay, super as NDIS provider collapses
items.description: Up to 500 workers are fighting to recoup pay, super and entitlements after the collapse of a large disability support provider operating in New South Wales.

items.title: Behind Grok's mass digital undressing lies an 'unsurprising' truth
items.description: The X AI is not creating sexually explicit images of women on its own, but the software "facilitates their abuse" acting on the requests of men "eager to violate women".

items.title: Greens won't support Labor's sweeping hate law reform in current form
items.description: The Greens have thrown up a roadblock for Labor by declaring it will not support the government's sweeping changes to hate and gun laws without amendments as the Coalition also backs away from the reforms.

items.title: Cars washed to sea, rain record smashed in Great Ocean Road deluge
items.description: People in a popular holiday region have been issued with an emergency warning after a storm cell dumped more than 100 millimetres of rain, flooding campsites.

items.title: Arctic wildfires reach highest intensity in 3,000 years

featured_image.name: Zombie fires" spark highest-ever carbon emissions in the ...

items.description:
Wildfires scorching the Arctic have reached levels unseen in 3,000 years, as rising temperatures transform the frozen north into an increasingly flammable landscape, according to a new NASA report and recent scientific studies.

The number of wildland fires burning in the Arctic is on the rise, with blazes burning larger, hotter, and longer than in previous decades, researchers say. The burned area in the North American Arctic has roughly doubled compared to the mid-20th century, and the mid-2010s ushered in what scientists describe as a novel fire regime.[1][2][3]

"Fire has always been a part of boreal and Arctic landscapes, but now it's starting to act in more extreme ways that mimic what we've seen in the temperate and the tropical areas," said Jessica McCarty, Deputy Earth Science Division Chief at NASA's Ames Research Center and lead author of a 2025 Arctic Monitoring and Assessment Programme report.[4][1]

items.title: Google's Gemini to tap Gmail, photos for personalized AI responses

featured_image.name: Google’s Gemini AI will use what it knows about you from Gmail, Search, and YouTube

items.description:
Google is making its biggest push yet to transform its Gemini AI assistant into both a personal shopper and a deeply personalized assistant, announcing two major features this week that integrate with leading retailers and tap into users' Gmail, photos, and search history.

The tech giant on Wednesday launched Personal Intelligence, a new beta feature that allows Gemini to access and analyze data across Gmail, Google Photos, YouTube watch history, and Search to deliver tailored responses. The feature is rolling out to Google AI Pro and AI Ultra subscribers in the United States, with plans to expand internationally and to free-tier users in the future.[1][2][3]

items.title: Musk's xAI disables Grok's sexualized image feature amid global backlash
items.description:
Elon Musk's xAI announced Wednesday it has disabled Grok's ability to create sexualized images of real people, following weeks of global outcry over the chatbot generating nonconsensual deepfakes of women and children. The policy shift comes as the Pentagon simultaneously moves to integrate Grok into military networks.

"We have implemented technological measures to prevent the Grok account from allowing the editing of images of real people in revealing clothing such as bikinis," X's safety team said in a statement. "This restriction applies to all users, including paid subscribers."[1][2][3]

items.title: Politicising Bondi backfires for Liberals who got what they asked for
items.description: Federal Liberals are discovering the price of having been so brazen in their politicisation of the Bondi terror attack and many appear to have buyers' remorse.

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.title: Trump-Putin Call Amid Ukraine-Russia Tensions Over Peace Plan
items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
